figure_2.title: Fig. 2.
figure_2.caption: Tokenization and Dependency parsing: In this example, the keyword “Multiple sclerosis” is tokenized to “Multiple” and “sclerosis” separately with parts of speech Adjective and Noun respectively

figure_3.title: Fig. 3.
figure_3.caption: HLA-SPREAD search: A screenshot of HLA-SPREAD to assist user in understanding HLA-SPREAD interface and easy retrieval of data

figure_4.title: Fig. 4.
figure_4.caption: Nature and trends of HLA related publications in PubMed annually from 1975 onwards: Stacked Bar plot shows distribution of PubMed articles in different categories. a Diverse studies including clinical trials are reported, with maximum numbers represented in the “journal article” category. b A subplot of (a) after removing the most frequent “Journal article” type to visualise the trends in other categories

figure_5.title: Fig. 5.
figure_5.caption: The topmost reported HLA alleles associated with diseases: All the HLA alleles indicated have been grouped to their second digit and represented in the pie chart. HLA-A, HLA-B and HLA-DRB1 are the most studied amongst the HLA genes

figure_6.title: Fig. 6.
figure_6.caption: Diseases/conditions associated with HLA genes: Graph represents three level hierarchy of diseases. Each colour represents a level. There are 24 major categories as represented in green colour, which is further divided into subcategories. Each disease name is matched to its Mesh id and a normalised mesh keyword. Autoimmune, Neoplasms and Joint disease are the top most associated diseases. As anticipated, significant numbers of studies related to transplantation are also observed

figure_7.title: Fig. 7.
figure_7.caption: Heatmap of HLA Disease associations: The gradient heat map representing the number of diseases associated with HLA genes. First column represents generic “HLA” studies where specific gene information is not mentioned. A large number of associations were also observed with Non-classical (HLA-E,F,G) genes

figure_8.title: Fig. 8.
figure_8.caption: Genomic distribution of SNPs: Pie chart representing the number of variations in genic region with majority of them mapping to introns

claims.sentence: We provide HLA-SPREAD (Fig. 1) as a platform for integrated HLA resources that has been developed using NLP to understand the complexity of this locus.
Direct implementation of word tokenization, first step in dependency parsing, generates multiple tokens for single allele and disease keywords as shown in Fig. 2.
Figure 3 gives insights in using the HLA-SPREAD search.
To understand the distribution of various kinds of articles published among the filtered abstracts, we studied the article type per year trend from 1975 to 2021 (Fig. 4).
To represent these alleles in the form of a graph, we collapsed the nomenclature to two-digit level (Fig. 5).
Figure 6 represents a snapshot of common HLA associated diseases.
We observed the majority of reported associations with HLA-DRB1, followed by HLA-B and HLA-A (Fig. 7).
Figure 8 represents genomic distribution of mapped SNPs.
Figure 9 represents the frequency distribution of these matched populations belonging to the countries and ethnic groups.
We also validated our results with AFND, a manually curated database that has information about ADRs and PharmGKB (Fig. 10a and b).
Figure 10c lists the frequency-based distribution of top 20 drugs fetched from our analysis.
